ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This semester, I improved my speaking skills and grammar and vocab knowledge. I enjoyed using more cultural materials and watching Israeli television.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the course made great use of the course packet and cultural resources like videos, games and tv shows. I liked that the small class size meant we could get to know each other better and talk more honestly. However, my biggest criticism of the class was that there was very little consistency in terms of peoples' Hebrew knowledge or speaking skills, and a very disparate number of undergraduates vs. graduate students and auditors, which made conversing or even getting through course material very slow and sometimes frustrating. I think if there had been more common ground or a baseline level of Hebrew knowledge that the class shared, we could have been way more productive and had really fun conversations. I often felt like I was the only one consistently participating in class and watching the shows for homework, and I frequently had to explain things that I've already learned in my 4 semesters of Hebrew here to classmates that had never learned them.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class but with the caveat that, like with most languages, you get out of it what you put into it.
